The electrocatalytic oxygen evolution reaction (OER) represents a pivotal process at the cathode of next-generation electrochemical storage and conversion technologies, among of them, OERs incorporating a single transition metal (TM) atom exhibit considerable potential for supplanting noble metals as electrochemical catalysts for fuel cells and metal-air batteries. Therefore, in this paper, we elucidated impacts of the TM monoatomic sites on the catalytic activity of OER on graphene-like BC2P monolayer through the utilization of density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Analysis of electronic structure reveals that the hybridised antibonding orbitals formed by the TM-3d and O-2p orbitals possess low-energy and high-occupancy properties, which weaken the OH-TM interactions and thus affect the catalytic activity of TM-N3 active site. Among all considered active sites, the Ni-N3 and Cu-N3 sites exhibited the most favourable OER catalytic performance, with the OER overpotential of the Ni-N3 site being only 0.42 eV, indicating an extremely high level of catalytic efficiency. Additionally, by exploring the coordination environment around the TM atoms, our study proposed a macroscopic descriptor and established a linear relationship between the catalytic performance and the descriptor using the linear regression. Therefore, our work offered theoretical guidance for the design of new and efficient OER catalysts, and further established a link between the microscopic mechanism of action and the macroscopic performance of catalysts, which providing new ideas for the development of high-performance catalytic materials. Introduction The utilization of traditional carbon-based fuels, including coal, oil and natural gas, has resulted in significant environmental damage and depletion of natural resources. These have been manifested in various forms, including environmental pollution, global climate change, scarcity of natural resources and inefficient using of energy, respectively [1,2]. Consequently, researchers are actively developing new energy conversion systems. At present, a number of innovative mechanisms and methods, including the electrolysis of water to produce hydrogen, carbon dioxide reduction, nitrogen reduction, fuel cells and metal-air batteries, have shown considerable potentials for industrial applications [3–5]. In these catalytic processes, clean energies, such as electricity, wind and solar energy, have provided a pathway to the production of high-value added products, for example, hydrogen, carbon-based fuels and nitrogen fertilizers, respectively. Therefore, people can not only complete the cycling of elements, such as carbon and nitrogen elements in the natural environments, but also can help to alleviate the problems of environmental pollution and energy scarcity [6,7]. The efficiency of oxygen evolution reaction (OER) as an anode reaction for water decomposition have direct impacts on the overall process of energy consumption and the cost of hydrogen productions. Similarly, in fuel cells, the efficiency of OER is also correlated to the performance and life time of the cell [8]. Then the development of efficient OER catalysts is particularly important for reducing the overpotential required for cell operation, increasing the energy conversion efficiency and extending the lifetime, respectively. Given central role of the OER in energy conversion technologies, enhancing its efficiency is crucial for reducing costs, improving energy efficiency and accelerating technology commercialization, respectively. However, the OER processes were typically constrained by high energy thresholds and slow kinetics, which impeded their efficiency in practical applications. The implementation of efficient OER catalysts can effectively reduce the overpotential, which reduces the energy loss and improves the performance of system. Nevertheless, despite of possessing remarkable catalytic activity, the existing catalysts, particularly the catalysts based on ruthenium and iridium oxides, are challenging to be implemented on a large scale due to their scarcity and high cost of precious metals. Moreover, these catalysts are prone to structural degradation or deactivation under extreme OER conditions, such as high potential and strong oxidation, which affects their long-term stability and durability [9–11]. On the other hand, it is noteworthy that the mining and refining processes of precious metals may harm the environment, which further emphasizes the urgency of developing economical, environmentally friend and sustainable OER catalysts. Therefore, the development of new OER catalysts is essential for the continued advancement of clean energy technologies. Catalysts which comprising low-cost transition metal (TM) elements are highly sought after for a number of chemical reactions, and these reactions involve nitrogen reduction [12], water decomposition [13,14], oxygen reduction and oxygen evolution, respectively [5,15]. In recent years, the embedding of TM atoms into carbon-based materials have enabled efficient utilization of these atoms, which demonstrating great potentials on the replacement of noble metal catalysts [16,17]. Due to the reductive nature of most TMs, they can react with oxygen molecules, and it has been demonstrated that the active site of modified graphene catalysts is TM-N x [18,19]. Moreover, for different metal atoms, the optimal coordination numbers of nitrogen atoms varies, for example, Fe-N4 [4], Fe-N3 [20], Ni-N3 [21], Cu-N2 [22], Mn-N3 [23], Co-N4 [24]. Additionally, other foreign atoms, such as boron, phosphorus and sulfur, can be grappled on graphene to modulate the kinetic activity of TM-N x sites [16,20,25,26]. Therefore, the non-uniform distribution of electrons enhances the catalytic activity, and coordination situation of the TM atoms is crucial for tuning the electronic structure around them and for achieving desired OER performance [6,27,28]. On the other hand, nowadays, rapid developments of high-performance computation and chemical technologies have resulted in the progresses on theoretical prediction and experimental verification, and an increasing number of novel two-dimensional (2D) materials have been predicted or verified in experiments. In 2023, our group predicted a new 2D material, namely BC2P monolayer, which is an ideal anode material for lithium-ion batteries and an adsorbent material for efficient carbon dioxide capture [29,30]. Concurrently, the composition of material includes non-precious metal elements, which confers an advantage over precious metal-based materials in terms of environmental impact and cost. Furthermore, high chemical activity of the BC2P monolayer surface facilitates the enhancement of its properties through chemical modification. Especially, the BC2P monolayer have a crystal structure similar to graphene, and thus liking graphene it can be used as an alternative substrate to sustain TM-N x active sites without any loss of activity [31]. Therefore, in this paper we employed the density functional theory (DFT) calculations to assess the OER catalytic activity of TM-N3 (TM = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) embedded in a supercell of the BC2P monolayer. During the evaluation process, we assessed the structural stability of TM-N3 embedded in the supercell of BC2P monolayer and established the scalar relation between the adsorption free energies of each intermediate. In addition, analysis of different descriptors provided insights into the mechanism on the excellence of TM-N3@BC2P monatomic catalysts in terms of OER catalytic performance. Computational methods The VASP software package was employed to perform the calculations of relaxation and electronic properties for all structures. For the exchange-correlation interactions between electrons, Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was selected to describe [32], and the pseudopotential was constructed using the projector augmented wave (PAW) pseudo-potentials [33], respectively. To construct the substrate model, a 5 × 3 × 1 BC2P supercell was selected and a 25 Å vacuum layer was added in the z-axis direction to avoid interactions between periodic BC2P monolayers. When calculating the electron wave function, a truncation energy of 500 eV was employed, and during the structural relaxation phase, all atomic positions were allowed to relax completely until the degrees of freedom per each atom were below 0.02 eV/Å. Furthermore, the convergence threshold for electron energy relaxation was set to 10–6 eV, and throughout the calculations we considered the spin polarization and remote van der Waals interactions by utilizing the DFT-D3 semi-empirical correction [34]. Additionally, the Brillouin zone was sampled using the Monkhorst-Pack (MP) method for meshing, and a 2 × 2 × 1 K-point grid was employed for structural relaxation and frequency calculations, while a denser 5 × 5 × 1 grid was used to calculate the self-consistent total energy and electronic structure [35], respectively. In order to calculate the vibrational frequencies, the catalyst surface was fixed, while only the vibrational models of reaction intermediates have been calculated. Current understanding of the reaction mechanism on OER is that it can be splitted into two main categories: lattice oxygen mechanism (LOM) and adsorbate evolution mechanism (AEM) [36,37]. Among of these, the AEM is a traditional OER mechanism, in which O atoms of the intermediates are derived from the oxygen atoms of H2O in the electrolyte. Moreover, in the AEM, the precipitation of oxygen molecules is contingent upon a series of oxidation reactions which adsorbed oxygen atoms on the surface. And in an alkaline condition, OER can be expressed as 4OH− = 2H2O + O2 + 4e−. The reaction steps of OER are as follows: OH−+∗→OH∗+e −, OH∗+OH−→O∗+H2O+e −, O∗+OH−→OOH∗+e −, OOH∗+OH−→O2 +∗+ H2O +e −. The active site of catalyst surface involves three intermediates: OH*, O* and OOH*. Therefore, the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model [38] was used to compute the free energy changes ( Δ G 1 , Δ G 2 , Δ G 3 , Δ G 4 ) for four elementary steps of OER in the alkaline electrolyte. (1) Δ G 1 = Δ G O H * − e U (2) Δ G 2 = Δ G O * − Δ G O H * − e U (3) Δ G 3 = Δ G O O H * − Δ G O * − e U (4) Δ G 4 = 4.92 − Δ G O O H * − e U The overpotential η O E R for the OER is obtained from the values of η O E R at U = 0 V as follows (5) η O E R = max { Δ G 1 , Δ G 2 , Δ G 3 , Δ G 4 } / e − 1.23 where e is elementary charge, 1.23 V is the equilibrium potential versus reversed hydrogen electrode (RHE). Δ G was calculated through the examination of zero-point energy and entropy correction, namely Δ G = Δ E + Z P E − T Δ S . Additionally, the formation energy of TM-N3 embedded to the BC2P monolayer can be evaluated by the following expression (6) E f = E T M − N 3 @ B C 2 P + E B / P + 3 E C − E p r i s t i n e − E T M − 3 E N (7) E f = E T M − N 3 @ B C 2 P + 2 E B / P + E B / P + E C − E p r i s t i n e − E T M − 3 E N where E T M − N 3 @ B C 2 P is total energy of the TM-N3@BC2P catalyst and E p r i s t i n e is total energy of the BC2P monolayer. E T M is the chemical potential of TM atom decided by the total energy per atom in TM bulk crystal. E B , E C , E P , E N are the chemical potentials of B, C, P and N atoms, which are decided by the total energy per atom in borophene, graphene, phosphene and nitrogen molecule, respectively. Results and discussions The BC2P monolayer exhibits similar crystal structure as graphene, as illustrated in Fig. 1 (a). Lattice parameters of the BC2P monolayer are a = 2.82 Å and b = 4.87 Å , and the lengths of its B-C and C-P bonds are 1.57 Å and 1.69 Å which are in good agreement with preceding results [30]. A number of potential adsorption sites at the supercell of BC2P monolayer were considered, which included the top sites of B, C1, C2 and P labelled by T1, T2, T3 and T4, and two non-equivalent vacancies denoted as H1 and H2, respectively. As illustrated in Fig. 1(c), one can find the OH and OOH intermediates exhibited an adsorption preference at the T4 site, whereas the O intermediates demonstrated an adsorption preference at the bridge location between the T3 and T4 sites which corresponds to a lower energy. This result indicates that the O atom forms chemical bonds with both C and P atoms. Fig. 1(b) depicted the free energy diagram of OER on the BC2P supercell with an overpotential of 0.85 V, and from the figure one can observed that the rate-determining step was the hydroxylation of O atom to form OOH. A multitude of studies have corroborated the assertion that TM-N x represents the pivotal active site of modified graphene catalysts [16,23,39,40]. For different metal atoms, its optimal coordination number of nitrogen atoms varies due to differences on the valence electron number, such as, Fe-N3, Mn-N4 and Co-N4 [20,23,24]. Similarly, foreign atoms, including boron, sulfurand phosphorus atoms, can be also anchored into the graphene to modulate the kinetic activity of TM-N x site. Therefore, in light of these findings, we devised 36 TM-N3@BC2P single-atom catalyst candidate systems which comprising nine TM atoms (Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) as shown in Fig. 2 , and these atoms were positioned on distinct sites within the BC2P substrate. Based on these designs, we considered the possibility on replacing one of B, C1, C2 or P atoms by a TM atom. The doping of N atoms was exploited to form TM-N3 coordination bonds using their lone electron pairs, which stabilizing the individual TM atoms and preventing metal agglomeration. The formation energies of TM atoms anchored to different sites on the BC2P substrate were calculated separately, as shown in Fig. 3 (a). It is evident that all the formation energies are negative, indicating that these TM atoms can be stably anchored on the BC2P substrate. Further observation reveals that the TM atoms have more negative formation energies when replacing B or P atoms, indicating stronger interactions with the substrate [41,42]. Conversely, the TM atoms have relatively weaker interactions with the substrate when replacing C atoms. Specifically, the TM atoms were observed to prefer replacing the P atom site to form more stable TM-N3@BC2P configurations. As shown in Fig. 3(b), the dissolution potentials of the catalysts were calculated by substituting TM-N3 for the P atom configuration. The results demonstrate that the dissolution potentials are all greater than zero, indicating that the catalysts exhibit resistance to dissolution in the electrolyte and, consequently stability. Furthermore, the negative formation energy and positive dissolution potential collectively suggest that the catalysts exhibit high stability in the electrolyte, rather than high solubility. Subsequently, the objective of our study concentrates on the most stable TM-N3@BC2P configurations and investigates their OER catalytic activities. In contrast to the highly symmetric TM-N bonds on graphene, the TM-N3 bond lengths in the BC2P supercell are not unique. This is due to the differences on the coordination environment of each N atom, which results in an uneven distribution of electrons. Consequently, the surface of BC2P supercell exhibits higher catalytic activity compared to the graphene. Following the introduction ofTM-N3 configurations, an electron transfer occurs between the BC2P supercell and TM-N3, and this has resulted in a significant narrowing of their band gap. In particular, at the Fermi level certain configurations may exhibit non-zero density of states (DOS), which means the transition from the semiconducting to the metallic properties as illustrated in Fig. 4 (a)–(i). In particular, from the figures one can see the bandgaps of system for the Ti-N3, Mn-N3, Fe-N3, Ni-N3 cases in Fig. 4(b), Fig. 4(e), Fig. 4(f) and Fig. 4(h) are significantly reduced, respectively. In contrast, for the Sc-N3, V-N3, Cr-N3, Co-N3, Cu-N3 cases in Fig. 4(a), Fig. 4(c), Fig. 4(d), Fig. 4(g) and Fig. 4 (i) respectively, the system undergo a transition from a semiconductor to the metallic nature. Therefore, one can conclude that the BC2P supercell which embedded with different TM-N3 exhibit excellent electronic conductivity. Additionally from Fig. 4(a)–(i), there have DOS differences for the spin-up and spin-down states. These differences may mainly come from the spin-orbit coupling effect of transition metal monoatomic catalysts, as well as the presence of unpaired electrons in catalysts and spin-polarized surface states on the surface of monatomic catalyst also show effects on the DOS distributions. The OER properties on the TM-N3 active sites are primarily influenced by the adsorption free energies of the key oxygen-containing intermediates OH, O and OOH. As illustrated in Fig. 5 (a), except for the Sc-N3 site, the adsorption free energies for different TM-N3 sites exhibit an increasing relation to the TM atomic number, and there exists a discernible correlation among of the adsorption free energies for three intermediates. Moreover, based on Sabatier's principle and the linear scaling relationships (LSRs) between adsorption energies of the OER intermediates, a volcanic linear model was constructed between the adsorption energy of oxygen atoms and the theoretical overpotential ofmaterial OER. Thus, this model enables prediction of the catalytic performance of OER catalysts based on the adsorption energy of oxygen intermediates. Furthermore, Fig. 5(b) illustrates the scaling relation between free energies of each individual intermediate states, and this linear relationship was obtained by linear regression as follows (8) Δ G O O H * = 0.91 Δ G O H * + 2.8 (9) Δ G O * = 1.03 Δ G O H * + 0.76 Among the aforementioned variables, the decisive coefficient between Δ G O O H * and Δ G O H * is as high as R 2 = 0.95 , indicating a strong linear relationship established. Indeed, for the TM-N3 embedded graphene, a comparable relationship between Δ G O O H * and Δ G O H * has been also documented [27,43]. The determination coefficient of the linear relationship between Δ G O * and Δ G O H * is R² = 0.92. The discrepancy between the predicted and theoretically calculated values was determined by means of the fitted linear equation, resulting in the root mean square error (RMSE). The results demonstrated that RMSEs of the fitted linear Eqs. (8) and (9) were 0.25 and 0.48, respectively. These values indicate that the equations effectively describe the linear relationship between OH* and O*, OOH* [44,45]. The scaling relationship among of Δ G O O H * , Δ G O * and Δ G O H * provides a basis on evaluating the overpotential of OER by setting Δ G O H * as a single dependent variable. Furthermore, the volcano plot of negative overpotential − η O E R against Δ G O H * was shown in Fig. 5(c). From the figure, the maximum value of − η O E R is demonstrated at Δ G O H * = 0.82 eV , and the Ni-N3 active site indicates the most significant OER catalytic performance. Free energy diagrams of the OER on the active sites TM-N3 (TM = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni and Cu) have been further calculated, and Fig. 6 show the free energy diagrams of Cu-N3 and Ni-N3 which have the best OER catalytic performance. From Fig. 6(a), for the Cu-N3 active site the OER overpotential η O E R = 0.52 e V is the decisive step, and the deprotonation of OH* to O* is the rate-determining step. At this moment, the catalytic performance of BC2P catalyst is evidently enhanced in comparison to that of the pristine BC2P catalyst because of its overpotential of 0.82 eV. Furthermore, Fig. 6(b) show the OER free energy diagram for the Ni-N3 active site, which owns the best catalytic performance among all considered TM-N3 active sites because of its overpotential as only η O E R = 0.42 e V , and corresponding rate-determining step is the hydroxylation from O* to OOH*. In addition, by comparing with the OER free energy overpotentials on the graphene-Fe-N3, the TM-N3@BC2P show better OER catalytic performance [46]. Electronic structure of the TM-N3 active site is a crucial factor to the high catalytic activityduring the OER process. Fig. 7 presented projected density of states (PDOS) of the 3 d orbitals for a single TM (TM = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni and Cu) atom and 2 p orbitals for the oxygen atom in OH*, respectively. 3 d z 2 , 3 d y z , 3 d x z , 3 d x y and 3 d x 2 orbitals represent 3d orbitals of the TM atom, and the occupancy of 3 d orbitals increase from the Sc to the Cu element because the number of empty and half-filled orbitals varies for diverse TM atoms. The differing interactions between the O- 2 p orbitals and the TM- 3 d orbitals result in two playing distinct roles in the vicinity of the Fermi level. Following the interaction of adsorbate molecular energy level with the TM d-electronic state, a higher energy antibonding state and a lower energy bonding state were formed between the adsorbate and the surface. Moreover, for the case of a hybridized adsorbate and catalyst surface, when the bonding state and the final antibonding state are occupied by electrons, the strongest interaction between two states occurs, while for the antibonding state no interaction exist [47,48]. The reason is that the antibonding state is not occupied by electrons, and thus the adsorption energy reaches its maximum value. Conversely, if the antibonding state is occupied by electrons, the interaction between the adsorbate and the surface will be weakened. Therefore, in the event that the generated antibonding state is below the Fermi level and the number of electrons occupying the antibonding state increases, the interaction is weakened accordingly. It was generally recognized that the greater for the charge transfer the stronger for the interaction between the active sites and the adsorbates, therefore, one can reasonably assume that there exists a correlation between Δ G OH * and the number of transfered charges q from the TM-N3 embedded BC2P supercell to the OH. We further performed Bader charge analysis accordingly, and found that the value of Δ G OH * decreased with the increasing of transferred charges. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 8 (a), using the polynomial fitting we also found that this relationship could be expressed by a quadratic function as follows (10) Δ G O H * = 148.95 q 2 − 181.06 q + 52.65 From the function, the determination coefficient between the number of transferred charges q and Δ G OH * is R 2 = 0.8 3, which has been presented in Fig. 8(a). On the other hand, the d band center theory [49] has been demonstrated to be a descriptor which can be employed to characterize the adsorption energy of small molecules, as illustrated in Fig. 8(b). Similarly, we related Δ G OH * to the d band center ε d , and the results demonstrated that the interaction between adsorbates and the catalyst surface was weakened with the lowering of d band center. This finding is consistent with the results of previous studies [30,50,51], and the determination coefficient between ε d and Δ G OH * is R 2 = 0.88 . Although the free energy of OH adsorption on the TM-N3 active site Δ G OH * is a valid descriptor for evaluating the performance of OER, it remains not a practical descriptor for the applications in experiments. Nevertheless, it is impractical in experiments although DFT calculations are necessary to determine the value of Δ G OH * . Therefore, in order to offer a more feasible guide to the rational design of suitable catalysts, it is significant to propose a macroscopic descriptor whose value can be easily derived from atomic properties. Then the macroscopic descriptor φ , inspired by the work of Xu et al., can be used to expressthe atomic properties of a single TM atom and the nearest three N atoms [27,45], and its definition is (11) φ = θ d χ T M + α 1 χ N + α 2 χ N + α 3 χ N χ O where θ d represents the number of 3 d orbitals occupied by the TM elements, and the Bowring electron egativities of TM, N and O atoms in the equation were designated as χ T M , χ N and χ o , respectively. Finally, the modification coefficients α 1 , α 2 and α 3 were determined by the coordination environments of N atoms. In contrast to N-doped graphene [27], the nitrogen atoms in BC2P supercell are no longer coordinated with the C atoms while coordinated with the B or P atoms. This situation enhances the ability of TM-N3 active sites to receive more electrons, which in turn enhances the OER catalytic performance. Additionally, for the N atoms which were coordinated with B and P atoms, their macroscopic descriptor φ can be corrected by setting α = χ P / χ B = 1.05 . Accordingly, the macroscopic descriptor φ is defined as (12) φ = θ d χ T M + 1 χ N + 1.05 χ N + 1.05 χ N χ O = χ T M + 3.1 χ N χ O From a physical perspective, there has existed a notable correlation between the number of occupied d orbitals θ d and the adsorption energy of intermediates, however, this relationship is not linear any more. The utilizations of χ T M and 3.1 χ N enabled the calibration of this scaling relationship to be effectively achieved. Concurrently, χ O ensures that the macroscopic descriptor φ remains dimensionless. Fig. 9 (a), Fig. 9(b) and Fig. 9(c) illustrates the scaling relationship between Δ G O H * , Δ G O * , Δ G O O H * and the macroscopic descriptor φ , and a linear regression analysis was conducted to derive the linear relationship as follows (13) Δ G O H * = 0.14 φ − 3.59 (14) Δ G O * = 0.22 φ − 4.75 (15) Δ G O O H * = 0.14 φ − 0.56 The R² and RMSE of the fitted linear equations were 0.90, 0.97, 0.95 and 0.37, 0.31, 0.24, respectively. The small errors associated with these values indicate that the results obtained are reliable. Although the free energy values must be obtained through DFT calculations, which inevitably introduce some degree of error, the macroscopic descriptors offer an optimal balance between reasonable precision and accuracy. The volcano plots of negative overpotentials − η O E R against the macroscopic descriptor φ was presented in the Fig. 9(d). By analyzing the linear relationship between − η O E R and φ , it can be observed that the volcano plot exhibits a similar degree with the plot in Fig. 5(c), indicating that the optimal active site for the OER catalytic performance occurs at φ = 32. In particular, the TM-N3 active site on the BC2P supercell is capable of balancing the adsorption free energy for all intermediates when φ is close to 32. Therefore, the descriptor φ provides a simple and effective guideline on the study and design of new families of high-performance single-atom catalysts. Conclusions High-performance catalysts are essential for accelerating the kinetics of slow OER. In this paper, graphene-like BC2P monolayer has been used as an alternative substrate to support the TM-N3 active site, and thereby to enhance the catalytic performance of OER. The TM-N3@BC2P catalysts show high potentials as outstanding performance catalysts, and their OER catalytic performances have been evaluated by the spin-polarized DFT calculation method. Firstly, the TM-N3 active sites can be stably anchored to the supercell of BC2P monolayer, which ensures synthetic preparation of the catalyst in experiments, and the TM-N3@BC2P composites exhibit excellent electrical conductivity. Secondly, OER properties of the TM-N3 active sites are primarily determined by the adsorption free energies of the key oxygen-containing intermediates, namely OH, O and OOH, and the adsorption free energy increases with the increasing of atomic number for different TM atoms. Furthermore, the Cu-N3 and Ni-N3 active sites demonstrated the most effective OER catalytic performance, with an OER overpotential of 0.52 eV and 0.42 eV, respectively. The rate-determining steps for the Cu-N3 and Ni-N3 active sites were identified as the deprotonation of OH to O and the hydroxylation of O to OOH, respectively. The objective of our study is to evaluate the catalytic performance of catalysts using a range of descriptors. As the atomic number of TM atoms increases, the d band center of TM atoms tend to shift from a high to a low energy level. In addition, the anti-bonding orbital shifts from above the Fermi level to a position near the Fermi level, and the occupancy of bonding orbitals decrease while the occupancyof antibonding orbitals increase. These factors collectively contribute to the reduction of interaction between the OH and TM-N3 active sites. Especially, we defined a macroscopic descriptor φ to predictthe catalytic performance of TM-N3 active sites on the BC2P supercell, and found that there indicated excellent OER catalytic performance when the descriptor φ =32. Therefore, the BC2P monolayer has been proved to be a novel material, which can support individual TM atoms in a manner analogous to graphene. More importantly, our work put forward the design principles on exploring new high-performance catalysts from both macroscopic and microscopic perspectives. coredata.dc:description: The electrocatalytic oxygen evolution reaction (OER) represents a pivotal process at the cathode of next-generation electrochemical storage and conversion technologies, among of them, OERs incorporating a single transition metal (TM) atom exhibit considerable potential for supplanting noble metals as electrochemical catalysts for fuel cells and metal-air batteries. Therefore, in this paper, we elucidated impacts of the TM monoatomic sites on the catalytic activity of OER on graphene-like BC2P monolayer through the utilization of density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Analysis of electronic structure reveals that the hybridised antibonding orbitals formed by the TM-3d and O-2p orbitals possess low-energy and high-occupancy properties, which weaken the OH-TM interactions and thus affect the catalytic activity of TM-N3 active site. Among all considered active sites, the Ni-N3 and Cu-N3 sites exhibited the most favourable OER catalytic performance, with the OER overpotential of the Ni-N3 site being only 0.42 eV, indicating an extremely high level of catalytic efficiency. Additionally, by exploring the coordination environment around the TM atoms, our study proposed a macroscopic descriptor and established a linear relationship between the catalytic performance and the descriptor using the linear regression. Therefore, our work offered theoretical guidance for the design of new and efficient OER catalysts, and further established a link between the microscopic mechanism of action and the macroscopic performance of catalysts, which providing new ideas for the development of high-performance catalytic materials.
